senses.de: To remove or erase something completely.
senses.ex: Please delete the unnecessary files from your computer.

Tips.title: Digital Cleanup
Tips.description: Used when tidying up electronic spaces, like clearing unnecessary data.
Tips.example: I regularly delete old documents to keep my folders organized.

Tips.title: Not for Trash
Tips.description: 'Delete' is not used for physical items; 'throw away' is more accurate for that.
Tips.example: Remember, we delete files, not papers.

Tips.title: Recoverability
Tips.description: In digital contexts, deleted items might be restored unless permanently erased.
Tips.example: Deleted photos can sometimes be recovered from a recycle bin.

senses.de: To decide not to include something.
senses.ex: The editor suggested to delete this paragraph to make the article more concise.

Tips.title: Editing Process
Tips.description: Often used to suggest removal for clarity or brevity in writing.
Tips.example: My teacher told me to delete redundant sentences from my essay.

Tips.title: Academic Context
Tips.description: Common in scholarly writing to indicate exclusion of text or ideas.
Tips.example: In my thesis, I had to delete several off-topic paragraphs.

senses.de: To stop a service on a machine or a software.
senses.ex: Delete your account if you no longer want our services.

Tips.title: Account Management
Tips.description: In computing, it implies removing access or stopping usage of a service.
Tips.example: After the trial period, I decided to delete my account.

Tips.title: Permanent Action
Tips.description: It implies a definitive action in digital services, usually irreversible.
Tips.example: Be careful when you delete a subscription, as you may lose all data.

senses.de: To scratch out or draw a line through something, often a text, to show it should be ignored.
senses.ex: He deleted her name from the list of participants.

Tips.title: Emphasize Removal
Tips.description: Indicates intent to disregard or not consider something or someone.
Tips.example: She deleted him from the guest list after their argument.

Tips.title: Physical Deletion
Tips.description: Refers to removing names or items from a physical list or document.
Tips.example: The teacher deleted the incorrect answers from the board.

Annihilate.wordDefinition:
Annihilate means to destroy completely, especially in a violent way. It is applicable in situations where complete destruction or elimination is required, such as in a war or when dealing with a deadly virus.

Think of it this way: annihilate is like blowing up a building, while delete is like erasing a word from a piece of paper.

Cancel.wordDefinition:
Cancel means to stop or remove something that was planned or requested.

It is often used when talking about plans, orders or subscriptions. For example, you would cancel a flight, a dinner reservation or a magazine subscription.

Cancel is used when stopping or ceasing something that was arranged or requested, while delete is used when removing something permanently, usually a digital file or document.

Efface.wordDefinition:
Efface means to erase or obliterate something completely, to the point where it is no longer visible or recognizable.

Delete means to remove, while efface means to completely erase or wipe out something.

Eliminate.wordDefinition:
Eliminate has a broader meaning and can be used in a variety of contexts. It means to remove or get rid of something completely, without leaving any traces of it behind.

For example, you can delete a file from your computer, but you eliminate a disease or a problem.

You can also use eliminate to refer to getting rid of a person, idea, or situation.

Delete is used when referring to the removal of digital content and eliminate is used when referring to the complete removal of something physical or abstract.

Erase.wordDefinition:
Erase means to completely remove or wipe out the data from a device. This action makes the data irretrievable and unrecoverable.

Erasing is more permanent than deleting and is primarily used when you don't want the data to be recovered by anyone.

In simple terms, deleting is like throwing a piece of paper in the trash can, while erasing is like shredding it to pieces. Deleting is reversible while erasing is not.

But if you want to sell or dispose of your device where you do not want any data to be recovered from it, you can use erase to remove all data.

Excise.wordDefinition: Excise means to remove a specific part of something. When you excise something, you are removing only a portion of it, not the entire thing.

Expunge.wordDefinition:
Delete means to remove or erase something from a computer or other electronic device. Expunge means to remove something completely, including any record or trace of it.

They are both applicable in situations where information needs to be removed or erased. For example, deleting a file from a computer or expunging a criminal record from someone's history.

However, the word expunge is usually used in more serious situations where the information being removed is considered damaging or harmful.

Obliterate.wordDefinition:
Obliterate means to completely destroy or eliminate something, often resulting in no trace of it remaining. For example, a bomb might obliterate a building, leaving nothing behind.

Delete is used for the removal of things, while obliterate is reserved for the complete destruction of objects or ideas.

Remove.wordDefinition:
The words delete and remove both mean to get rid of something, but they are used in slightly different contexts.

Remove is usually used for getting rid of something physical, like an object or a stain. For example, you might remove a stain from your clothes, or remove a piece of furniture from a room.

To put it simply, delete is used for digital things, while remove is used for physical things.

quotes.Text: Online one day, you log in, and you realise, 'This is not me.' Everything you're posting, you're doing it in the context of everything you've posted before. Let's delete everything, save the stuff that's important, and then you only have to organise the one per cent that's worth keeping.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Evan Spiegel

quotes.Text: We have a presidential candidate who's deleted emails and done things illegally and is a presidential candidate. That doesn't make sense to me, because if that was any other person, you'd be in prison. So what is this country really standing for?
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Colin Kaepernick

quotes.Text: My company has no intention of deleting constitutionally protected hate speech. I feel the remedy for this type of speech is counter speech, and I'm certain that this is the view of the American justice system.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Jim Watkins

quotes.Text: We're now seeing email that people thought they had deleted showing up as evidence in court. You can't erase email. As that becomes more commonly realized, people will be a little wiser about what they type.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Judith Martin

quotes.Text: You can't delete racism. It's like a cigarette. You can't stop smoking if you don't want to, and you can't stop racism if people don't want to. But I'll do everything I can to help.
quotes.Title: Italian Athlete
quotes.Name: Mario Balotelli

quotes.Text: It's very unusual on 'Game of Thrones' for there to be a deleted scene because the scripts are pretty locked in. There's rarely a reason to say, 'Hey, we don't need this scene.

quotes.Name: Alex Graves

quotes.Text: Substitute 'damn' every time you're inclined to write 'very'; your editor will delete it and the writing will be just as it should be.

quotes.Name: Mark Twain

quotes.Text: I'm on Twitter for work, but I hate it. I encourage everyone to delete it if possible.

quotes.Text: More than once, I've wished my real life had a delete key.
